title: Support auto-selecting `image_id` by OS version
body:
From user, whose app requires a specific Ubuntu 18.04 version, and does not support the latest 20.04 we use:

> Is there a way to specify the desired ubuntu version of the AWS AMI without specifying the AMI explicitly (basically have Sky find the compatible AMI for me)?
I’m trying to debug if some cryptic MPI errors is due to incompatibility between the ubuntu version (18.04) of singularity image (similar to docker) and the host ubuntu (20.04).

> indeed I need to make sure the OS version is matching, so confirming the utility of this image id customization feature for me.

This is related to #1345, but different.

-------

Sketching a potential interface, while many are possible:
```
resources:
  versions:  # These are filters for image_id's (at least we can start with AMIs).
    ubuntu: 18.04
    cuda: 11.6
```

title: Support passing multiple `image_id`, one per region
body:
From user, whose app requires a specific Ubuntu 18.04 version, and does not support the latest 20.04 we use:

> An alternative could be to allow specifying image_id as a mapping from region to AMI so that at least the user won’t be limited to specifying a fixed region. This would be more flexible (esp if user wants to use custom AMIs) but a bit more work on the user’s side.

Previously, @pounde also requested this feature.

-----

Proposal:
```
resources:
  image_id:
    us-east-1: <find your us-east-1 AMI>
    us-west-1: <find your us-west-1 AMI>
```
where SkyPilot will restrict itself to provision in these regions only.

title: Support more AWS regions for better spot availability
body:
From user

> It seems that Sky only tries a few regions like us-east-1, us-east-2, us-west-1, us-west-2 (from looking at https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/05d42185d6376cb6061b84f12068d39aa8693c95/sky/clouds/aws.py#L116), when there are other regions potentially with spot instance availability. Is this true & if so why not more regions?

> Would be great to have this option since it might provide more spot instance availability for me

title: `unattended-upgrade` process upon starting VM made `launch` get stuck
body:
User reported:
> A couple issues I encountered while trying to use an AMI for ubuntu 18.04: Upon starting the instance, an unattended-upgrade process runs in the background and blocks the initialization process (it holds the lock needed by apt-get). It might be good to allow doing sudo systemctl stop unattended-upgrades while preparing SkyPilot runtime.

Specifically it got stuck after
```
Successfully installed MarkupSafe-2.1.1 PrettyTable-3.5.0 awscli-1.26.4 boto3-1.25.4 botocore-1.28.4 colorama-0.4.4 commonmark-0.9.1 docutils-0.16 httplib2-0.21.0 jinja2-3.1.2 jmespath-1.0.1 networkx-2.8.7 oauth2client-4.1.3 packaging-21.3 pandas-1.5.1 pendulum-2.1.2 pulp-2.6.0 pycryptodome-3.12.0 pygments-2.13.0 pyparsing-3.0.9 python-dateutil-2.8.2 pytz-2022.5 pytzdata-2020.1 pyyaml-5.4.1 rich-12.6.0 rsa-4.7.2 s3transfer-0.6.0 skypilot-0.2.0 tabulate-0.9.0
```
After I force-killed the unattended upgrades process and removed lock files it then proceeded to
```
Setting up man-db (2.8.3-2ubuntu0.1) ...
```

----

cc @michaelzhiluo is this related to apt locks?

From a user:
> Sky seems to only register ssh config for the head node but not the worker nodes. I had to log into EC2 manually to figure out the IP addresses of worker nodes. Is there a more convenient option that I might be missing?

We should document clearly: `ssh cluster-name-worker1` (changing the number for different workers) to log into the workers.

title: [UX] Add environment variable `SKY_NUM_GPUS_PER_NODE`
body:
Closes #1334.

Tested:
- [x] The distributed yaml from the doc: `sky launch -c multi-node multi-node.yaml`
```
# multi-node.yaml
name: resnet-distributed-app

resources:
  accelerators: V100:4

num_nodes: 2

setup: |
  pip3 install --upgrade pip
  git clone https://github.com/michaelzhiluo/pytorch-distributed-resnet
  cd pytorch-distributed-resnet && pip3 install -r requirements.txt
  mkdir -p data  && mkdir -p saved_models && cd data && \
    wget -c --quiet https://www.cs.toronto.edu/~kriz/cifar-10-python.tar.gz
  tar -xvzf cifar-10-python.tar.gz

run: |
  cd pytorch-distributed-resnet

  num_nodes=`echo "$SKY_NODE_IPS" | wc -l`
  master_addr=`echo "$SKY_NODE_IPS" | head -n1`
  python3 -m torch.distributed.launch --nproc_per_node=$SKY_NUM_GPUS_PER_NODE \
    --nnodes=$num_nodes --node_rank=${SKY_NODE_RANK} --master_addr=$master_addr \
    --master_port=8008 resnet_ddp.py --num_epochs 20
```

title: [Feature Request] Export `SKY_NODE_IPS` and `SKY_NODE_RANK` outside of `run`
body: These two environment variables mentioned above are only accessible in the `run` function - when the Ray job is executed. This conflicts with distributed training, where these variables are needed in the setup step of the task. Hence, it is a good feature to have these environment variables earlier in stages of a Task.

title: [UX] access aws credentials on the remote VM as root
body:
A quote from a pilot user: "need to run a script that calls aws internally and then need to write to a path that requires sudo permission, and I’m trying to call the script with sudo"

We need to find a way to let the `sudo aws configure list` be able to access the credential file under `/home/ubuntu/.aws` as well.

title: [Test/Azure] Fix the torch version in examples for smoke test and change the credential for Azure
body:
Closes #1327 

PyTorch bumps up the version to `1.13.0` yesterday, which causes the cuda version mismatch problem, when directly installing the latest `PyTorch==1.13.0` `pip install torch`.

The backward compatibility should be guaranteed by our `_RAY_YAML_KEYS_TO_RESTORE_FOR_BACK_COMPATIBILITY` in `backend_utils.py`, as the ami is set in the `node_config` section.
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/855d4b46800d70597808d4c773e1f53e146bdbf8/sky/backends/backend_utils.py#L126

Update: Have to revert the aws/gcp/azure image, since failed `test_cancel_azure` (The latest `22.09.14` azure image has an older nvidia driver `470.141.03` cuda version `11.3` than our previous azure image `21.11.04` with nvidia-driver `495.29.05`, cuda `11.5`).

Future TODO:
- [ ] Ask the user to use older version of the pytorch to be able to run with CUDA lower than 11.6 #1333 

Tested:
- [x] `./tests/run_smoke_tests.sh`

title: [Spot] Fix race condition for spot logs
body:
This PR attempts to fix #1328.

The problem could happen due to a race condition, where the cluster is removed due to the preemption, but the `spot_status` has not been set to the correct state yet. In that case, the `handle` will be `None` and fails the log tailing.

i.e., after the following lines the cluster can be already removed from the cluster table, but the `spot_status` has not been set to `RECOVERING` yet.
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/a66aa263325cec34f28c36a7f16f7ca1b23d130d/sky/spot/controller.py#L101-L107

Tested:
- [x] `sky spot launch -n test-logs "echo hi; sleep 200"` and terminate the cluster manually. (it may not be exactly the same as the case in #1328, where the preemption may happen before the logging starts)

title: [Dependency] Fix colorama dependency issue with awscli
body:
Closes #1321 

The is caused by ray installing `colorama` for third-party packages without version constraint ([here](https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/03b6bc7b5a305877501110ec04710a9c57011479/python/setup.py#L529)), which somehow breaks the dependency of `awscli==1.25.8`, which is used in our storage. 

After this fix, the user may need to install again with `pip install .` to make the dependency take effect.

This PR also fixes a little bit of the UX for the `sky storage delete`

Tested:
- [x] `pip install ray[default]==2.0.1; pip install -e .; sky storage delete skypilot-filemounts-*` (there are multiple S3 buckets named `skypilot-filemounts-*`)

title: [Storage] Confusing logging in `sky storage delete`
body:
When I am trying to delete a storage object with `sky storage delete skypilot-filemounts-*`, the logging is quite confusing showing the bucket is detected, then the bucket is created, and finally the bucket is deleted.
```
I 10-29 00:50:56 storage.py:402] Detected existing storage object, loading Storage: skypilot-filemounts-folder-zhwu-301024cb-1
I 10-29 00:50:58 storage.py:1228] Created GCS bucket skypilot-filemounts-folder-zhwu-301024cb-1 in US-CENTRAL1 with storage class STANDARD
I 10-29 00:51:01 storage.py:1092] Deleted GCS bucket skypilot-filemounts-folder-zhwu-301024cb-1.
```

Probably, it is because the bucket has been deleted on the cloud console, but it is still in my storage table. Seems we will create a `sky.Storage` object (the creation will create a bucket during initialization) before calling `storage.delete()`

title: [Storage] Add lazy unmount flag
body:
Closes #1319.

This is caused when a process holds onto a file on the mounted path. Our fix makes the unmounting lazy (similar to `umount -l`), which will detach the filesystem from the filesystem hierarchy immediately, and cleanup all references to the filesystem as soon as it is released by the offending process.

Tested:
```yaml
file_mounts:
  /data:
    name: sky-romilb-test

run: |
  tail -f /dev/null > /data/myfile &
```
- [x] Multiple `sky launch` on both gcp and aws

title: [Storage] Error when launching another task with the same file mount
body:
Hi,

I'm repeatedly launching jobs on the same machine that use the same S3 mount point. On subsequent invocations, I run into an error when re-mounting:
```
echo "Mounting $SOURCE_BUCKET to $MOUNT_PATH with $MOUNT_BINARY..."
goofys -o allow_other --stat-cache-ttl 5s --type-cache-ttl 5s cloud-av-workloads /data
echo "Mounting done."
) && chmod +x ~/.sky/mount_785106.sh && bash ~/.sky/mount_785106.sh && rm ~/.sky/mount_785106.sh failed with return code 1.
Failed to run command before rsync cloud-av-workloads -> /data.
```
And here is the output of `storage_mounts.log`:
```
bash: warning: here-document at line 37 delimited by end-of-file (wanted `EOF')
Path already mounted - unmounting...
fusermount: failed to unmount /data: Device or resource busy
Successfully unmounted /data.
goofys already installed. Proceeding...
Mount path /data is not empty. Please make sure its empty.
```

I think this could be resolved by detecting whether the mount points are identical and keeping the file mount alive between jobs rather than unmounting and re-mounting.

I'm trying to mount an S3 bucket within my workdir. I used the following config, expecting `./data` to be a location within my workdir; however, it mounts to `~/data`. This is inconsistent with the behavior in `setup` and `run`, where `.` points to the workdir.

```

title: [Storage] add `--implicit-dirs` for gcsfuse
body:
Closes #1154.

`--implicit-dirs` flag for gcsfuse allows [implicitly defined directories](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/gcsfuse/blob/master/docs/semantics.md#implicit-directories) to show up in mounts. 

The [gcsfuse documentation](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/gcsfuse/blob/master/docs/semantics.md#implicit-directories) suggests this may have performance and cost implications. I did some simple performance measurements with and without `--implicit-dirs`. See benchmark numbers at the end.

* I don't see a significant performance difference with `--implicit-dirs` on or off. 
* It is hard to measure the cost implications, but I expect them to be [small](https://cloud.google.com/storage/pricing#operations-by-class).
* There exists an [alternative solution](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/gcsfuse/issues/7#issuecomment-264221351), which creates the directory objects right after mounting: 
```
BUCKET=my-bucket MOUNTED_AT=/path/to/mount; gsutil ls "gs://$BUCKET/*/*/**" | xargs dirname | sort | uniq | sed "s/gs:\/\/$BUCKET\///" | xargs -I % mkdir -p "$MOUNTED_AT/%"
```
* However, this alternative solution won't work for public bucket since the user may not have permissions to create directory objects on the bucket.

**Conclusion** - It should be okay to enable `--implicit-dirs`.


### Benchmark numbers
Using fio to measure sequential read performance:
```
fio --name=64kseqreads --rw=read --direct=1 --ioengine=libaio --bs=64k --numjobs=4 --iodepth=128 --size=1G --group_reporting --directory=/noimplicit/ --output-format=json > ~/perf_read_noimplicit.json
```
|                                   | With --implicit-dirs | Without --implicit-dirs |
|-----------------------------------|----------------------|-------------------------|
| Sequential Read Throughput (MB/s) | 267.13               | 262                     |
| Sequential Read IOPS              | 4076                 | 3994.25                 |

Using simple shell commands to test 100 small file read/write makespan:
```
time for i in {0..100}; do echo 'test' > "test${i}.txt"; done # Write
time for i in {0..100}; do cat "test${i}.txt" > /dev/null; done # Read
ls -la # stat operation
```
|                    | With --implicit-dirs | Without --implicit-dirs |
|--------------------|----------------------|-------------------------|
| Write Makespan (s) | 58.2s                | 57.1s                   |
| Read Makespan (s)  | 2.8s                 | 2.9s                    |
| ls Makespan (s)    | 7.3                  | 6.9                     |

title: Add cost tracking for clusters
body:
Addresses #1278

Uses metadata column of user cluster table to store start and stop times of cluster (manual, auto-stopping not handled as of now). 

When user gets status, table will show a Total Cost column that is the cost of the cluster (not disk storage, just cluster itself) from its inception until when the status query was made.  

When user stops or downs cluster, the total cost of the cluster until the stop/down will also be logged in CLI. 

When cluster is stopped, status calls will not show changes in cost (since here we only track cluster cost, not storage).

User can restart cluster and the new start time will be recorded too.

There are checks on the metadata column and base-cases to make sure that these changes are backwards-compatible (clusters that were launched with this type of tracking in metadata column).

Did manual testing by doing all of the above on a new cluster, and verifying features were backwards-compatible as I also had old, stopped clusters I could see status on and could re-start, giving them the metadata needed to begin cost-tracking. Also, verified that cost estimates are accurate by measuring time and calculating expected cost manually and comparing it to the estimates generated by the proposed changes.

CLI Test Output: 
```
(sky) sumanth@MacBook-Pro-5 sky_yamls % sky status
Clusters
NAME   LAUNCHED     RESOURCES             STATUS  AUTOSTOP  COST (est.)  COMMAND                       
mount  35 secs ago  1x GCP(n1-highmem-8)  UP      -         $ 0.011      sky launch -c mount clust...  

(sky) sumanth@MacBook-Pro-5 sky_yamls % sky stop mount

title: [Onprem] Supporting a Wider Range of GPUs
body: The GPUs reported by onprem users include 1080, 2080, A5000/6000, etc. We need to ensure that job submission can support these types of GPUs.

title: [Onprem] Automatically detect port issues when deploying
body:
During the `sky admin deploy`, it is possible for the process stuck forever at the `Waiting for workers` due to the port on the worker node not open. We need to:
1. set a timeout for the step
2. automatically detect the problem
3. add the instructions in the docs for opening ports (probably also detailed instruction for opening ports on the clouds)

title: Set `--rename-dir-limit` for gcsfuse to allow dir renames
body:
Closes #1281. 

The problem was stemming from gcsfuse not allowing directory renames, which is used by tensorflow-dataset. From gcsfuse docs:

> Renaming directories is by default not supported. A directory rename cannot be performed atomically in GCS and would therefore be arbitrarily expensive in terms of GCS operations, and for large directories would have high probability of failure, leaving the two directories in an inconsistent state.
> 
> However, if your application can tolerate the risks, you may enable renaming directories in a non-atomic way in gcsfuse starting v0.35.0, by setting --rename-dir-limit. If a directory contains fewer files than this limit and no subdirectory, it can be renamed.

This is a tradeoff between (cost, consistency) and functionality - you can have low cost and good consistency but you must disallow renames for large dirs.

SkyPilot now uses `--rename-dir-limit 10000`, which allows renames for dirs containing up to 10000 files. By setting this limit to 10000, we cap the max cost to $0.05 per dir rename to avoid users accidentally running a big storage bill if they are running frequent renames. 

The downside is any dir larger than 10000 files would raise a cryptic `Too many open files` error like in #1281.  I chose 10000 because most common datasets are only a few tens of large files. Lmk if you think we should use a different limit, happy to change. 

Tested:
- [x] YAML from #1281
- [x] `test_smoke::TestStorageWithCredentials`

title: Down Stage in `execution.py` is never called
body:
In the code here,
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/deb089dabf46485793f35992ed33999dc64cd6b8/sky/execution.py#L251-L254

`backend.teardown` is never called since when `down=True`, `idle_minutes_to_autostop` is set to 1 here:

https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/deb089dabf46485793f35992ed33999dc64cd6b8/sky/execution.py#L165-L182

In that case what is the purpose of `stages.DOWN`?

title: [UX/Programmatic API] Support task in launch/exec/spot_launch
body:
This PR is a proposal to support `sky.Task` in launch/exec/spot_launch directly in addition to our previous `sky.Dag` API. That is because none of our users is using the dag abstraction for now and we do not support dag with more than 1 task in our programmatic API.

- [x] `sky launch -c min echo hi`
- [x] `python ./examples/resnet_app.py`
- [x] `tests/run_smoke_tests.sh`

title: Fix Storage `persistent=False` Bug
body:
Fixes #1280 .

## Tests

```
# test.yaml
file_mounts:
  /dst:
    name: skypilot-zhwu-test-storage-persistent
    source: ~/tmpdir
    persistent: False

run: |
  echo hi
```

```
sky launch -c test-storage ./test.yaml
sky down test-storage
sky storage ls
```

title: Fix SKY_NODE_RANK environment variable
body:
As discussed in #1206, this PR ensures that SKY_NODE_RANK is always 0 on the head node, and that it is assigned to the worker nodes in a stable fashion when executing tasks on multi-node clusters. 

To accomplish this, in each call to `_execute_task_n_nodes`, we create a map of internal node ips to their correct rank, and pass this map into the Ray code generator, which assigns to correct rank to each node.

Tested:
- [x] Single-node cluster
- [x] Multi-node cluster using the following config
```
resources:
  cloud: aws
  disk_size: 1024
  instance_type: m6i.large

workdir: .

num_nodes: 4

run: |
  echo $SKY_NODE_RANK
```

title: [UX] Disable python output buffer by default
body: During the onboarding session, we observed that the user program's output with `tqdm` failed to output information after a while, due to not specifying `python -u`. We can set the environment variable to disable the buffering instaed.

title: [custom image] pip install fail in some custom image
body:
During the onboarding of a user, we found this issue. Installing ray/skypilot with the default pip3 can fail in some custom images due to the `permission denied` for writing to the default python package location. Adding `--user` in the ray yaml config to every `pip3 install` fixes her issue.

We need to re-consider where we install the dependencies of skypilot on the remote VM.

title: [Azure] Patch azure cli timeout issue
body:
Fixes #1273 

Before this PR, the error is deterministic. We patch the timeout by replacing the timeout value in the `azure.identity._credentials.azure_cli` from 10 to 30 (from https://github.com/Azure/azure-cli/issues/20404#issuecomment-1249575110)

Tested:
- [x] `sky launch -c test-azure --cloud azure echo hi`
- [x] `sky exec test-azure echo hi`
- [x] `sky launch -c test-azure --cloud azure echo hi`

title: [Launch/Backward Compatibility] Fix incorrect Ray YAML issue
body:
During offline debugging with @Michaelvll , we found that two things need to be fixed for https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/issues/1283.
- Handle error code for getting zone cmd
- in `write_cluster_config`, we generate Ray YAML and modify it multiple times. however, some error may happen before we finalize the YAML (e.g., some network error I met during connection with boto). Hence the Ray YAML became incomplete (this time SSH key wasn't added so we couldn't login to the server). And future sky launch will assume this YAML is correct and keep reusing it. hence caused the bug.

This PR fixes the above.

title: docs: document core programmatic APIs, and add them to docs website.
body:
This PR only handles the Core APIs -- the 7 functions backing https://skypilot.readthedocs.io/en/latest/reference/cli.html#core-cli. It does not properly go through core classes Task, Dag, etc. yet, which will be done in future PRs.

Made some minor changes to core funcs signatures; ran smoke tests to confirm they are working.

Tested
- [x] smoke tests
- [x] rendered HTMLs locally

title: Fix Sky Storage Delete more than 256 Items/folders + Bulk Deletion Tests
body:
Fixes #1267 

The bug was that `gsutil -m rm -a gs://asdf/*` did not delete directories on the first level. It is fixed now with `gsutil -m rm -a gs://asdf/**`

title: UX change to status table display.
body: Previously, the hint about auto{stop,down} was too dim to easily notice on a dark scheme terminal. This changes it to normal font, as it's an important message. @Michaelvll could you help check if this looks OK on a light theme? Also reworded some messages.

title: [UX] Launching on an existing cluster sets the state to INIT causing confusion
body:
One of our users is confused by the status of `sky launch -c existing_cluster` being INIT. It is confusing why the cluster will be re-initialized again and whether it creates another cluster. It would be good to clarify that. Here are 2 options:
1. Change the INIT state to SETUP, which will be easier to understand. (we can keep the internal status, but distinguish the display for launch a new cluster and launch on an existing cluster).
2. Re-design the logic of the `sky launch` so that it can skip the code path that sets the cluster status UP->INIT->UP. (This may require modifying many places, as internally we use INIT for many checks).

title: [Storage] Leakage of storage with persistent=False
body:
Our storage is not linked with the cluster or task, so when the job finishes or the cluster is terminated, the storage will not be deleted even if the `persistent=False` is set.

```
# test.yaml
file_mounts:
  /dst:
    name: skypilot-zhwu-test-storage-persistent
    source: ~/tmpdir
    persistent: False

run: |
  echo hi
```

```
sky launch -c test-storage ./test.yaml
sky down test-storage
sky storage ls
```

This should be also related to #1203, as we need to store the storage information in the clusters' metadata.
Also, the `autodown` may also cause leakage for the storage, even after we add the info to the metadata.
cc @romilbhardwaj @michaelzhiluo

title: [Feature Request] Different Types of Disk Storage
body:
So far, Skypilot, when it launches/provisions VMs, uses standard persistent disk storage for its VMs.
One user of Skypilot mentioned that there should be support for a different types of disk storage, such as Azure Premium SSD (https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/premium-storage-performance).

body: During a conversation with one of our potential users for Skypilot, he mentioned it would be a nice to have to support Azure Blob storage, since he only has credits for Azure.

title: [Spot] Show spot controller in sky status and simplify tearing down
body: According to the offline discussion with @concretevitamin, we decided to add the spot controller in the `sky status` to avoid confusion caused by the controller in the cloud console. (Part of the efforts for fixing #1269) After this PR, the `sky status` will be: When tearing down the controller, the output would be (no `--purge` required, as purging can lead to resource leakage): TODO: - [x] Merge #1269 - [x] Add docs for the modification in this PR.

title: [Docs] Spot controller missing from docs
body:
The docs lack information on how to manage the spot controller, especially on how to terminate the controller. We need to answer questions like:

1. Is the spot controller shared among tasks?
2. How long does the spot controller keep running?
3. I am uninstalling SkyPilot or I do not want to keep the controller stopped. How do I terminate the spot controller?

title: [Provisioner][Feature Request] Use quotas to guide region/cloud fail over
body:
Current failover logic iterates over a series of regions/cloud. However, often the reason for provisioning failures is the lack of quotas. User may have quota in just one region, but they must wait for failover to happen across many other regions first. (Of course they could specify the region in the yaml, but that's only if the user knows where they have quotas)

Can we obtain user's quotas from cloud APIs and use that to guide our failover logic?

title: [Core] Fix resource validation for existing cluster and refactor
body:
Fixes #1258 

This PR makes validation of the resources based on the offering for each region/zone, only when the resources is `launchable` and is being launched by the optimizer. This is because if the cluster already exists, the user can specify some combination of the accelerator / accelerator count that does not exist in the specified region/zone.

For example: aws only has A100:8 in a region, but the user can `sky exec cluster_name --region region_name --cloud aws --gpus A100:1` to schedule the job on the existing cluster. Our current master PR will block this behavior, as the A100:1 is not offered by the region.

The validation of the Resources for existing cluster will be done by https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/8d3fce2a166a1d83b741cdabdba152b0e2352623/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py#L2173-L2199

Note: This PR should be compatible with #1429 as the `validate_launchable` function should only be called by the resources that is meant to be used to create new VMs.

---

This PR also refactors the optimizer logic, so as to make the resource validation clearer.

We previously had two code paths for validating the requested resources causing our implementation for checking needs to be duplicated for requested resources that is launchable and not launchable . https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/15017087357912cfab5a58cdabf9723cfe52a0f3/sky/optimizer.py#L957-L1024

For example, in #2096, although we disable the spot instance in cloud.get_feasible_launchable_resoures and `sky launch --use-spot` will skip the k8s cloud, we can still get around that check by making the requested resources launchable: `sky launch --cloud kubernetes --instance-type 8CPU-16GB --use-spot`.

That said our current code is quite error-prone, making it easy to forget to update the two places for the check.
The refactoring should fix this, by always using the `get_feasible_launchable_resources`

---

Tested:
- [ ] `pytest tests/test_smoke.py`

title: [Core] Fail to launch task on existing cluster with odd GPU numbers when region/zone specified
body:
Reproducible code:
```
sky gpunode --gpus K80:4 --region us-central1 --cloud gcp -c test-gpu
sky exec --gpus K80:3 --region us-central1 test-gpu 'echo hi'
```
It raises:
```
Task from command: echo hi
ValueError: Accelerator "K80" is not available in "us-central1" region/zone.
```

However, `sky exec --gpus K80:2 --region us-central1 test-gpu 'echo hi'`works, which is inconsistent.

title: [Provisioner] Shared cloud credentials cause interference when same cluster name is used
body:
I am sharing AWS credentials (i.e., same `~/.aws/credentials`) between two machines `L1` and `L2`.

If I run `sky cpunode` on `L1`, it works. Then I log in to `L2` and `sky cpunode`, it also works however my SSH connection to cpunode on `L1` disconnects. Trying to reconnect from `L1` using `ssh sky-cpunode-root` or `sky cpunode` fails with `ssh: connect to host 34.207.226.133 port 22: Connection refused`.

More worryingly, if I run `sky down sky-cpunode-root` on `L1`, it kills the cpunode created by `L2`.

This appears to be related to two accounts sharing the same namespace for VMs in AWS. A simple fix would be to change the `sky cpunode` suffix to use a better hash for the cluster name suffix (`-<mac_hash>` instead of `-<username>`). A more robust fix would be to maintain a separate mapping of sky cluster name to unique VM name used for the cloud API (though I think that may make debugging with the cloud console harder).

title: [Provisioner] Add support for opening ports on VMs
body:
I want to host a publicly accessible jupyter notebook using SkyPilot, where I distribute IP and port number and my customers can simply type `http://IP:PORT/` in their browser to access the notebook. I can fetch the IPs of the machines provisioned by SkyPilot by inspecting `~/.sky/state.db`, but only port 22 is open on the VMs. Security is handled at the application layer (I distribute jupyter auth credentials).

It would be great to have functionality to open specific ports on VMs so users can host services with SkyPilot and expose them externally.

Note that this is about opening ports in the VM's security group, which is different from port-forwarding (supported by sky cpunode).

title: [Autodown] Better logging for `sky status -r` for autodown cluster
body:
As mentioned by @concretevitamin, the current logging. for `sky status -r` is a bit scary, when the cluster with autodown is terminated. This PR handles the logging for the clusters with autodown differently against the normal clusters.

The new logging for the clusters with autodown:
```
sky status -r                                                                                                                                          ✈ ✱
I 10-14 13:17:38 backend_utils.py:1819] The following cluster was autodowned and removed from the cluster table: test-autodown
NAME             LAUNCHED  RESOURCES             STATUS  AUTOSTOP  COMMAND                    
smoke-test-zhwu  1 hr ago  1x GCP(n1-highmem-8)  UP      -         sky start smoke-test-zhwu 
```
